CERTIFICATES.TITLE: Guidelines For Accreditation of Balint Leaders
CERTIFICATES.TEXT1: Proposed by the Leadership Task Force Approved by Council in Salzburg, Austria – 14 May, 2016
CERTIFICATES.TEXT2: These guidelines are intended as parameters for national societies to consider when drawing up their criteria for accreditation. National societies will want to define periods of sufficient lengths of time for being in a Balint Group, for instance. Societies need to be aware that it is equally important for psychiatrists and psychotherapists to acquire experience of leading Balint Groups before becoming accredited, as it is for GPs. And that the pathway for psychiatrists and psychotherapists will be different to the pathway for GPs.

LIST.1: Leaders should have appropriate basic professional training.
LIST.2: Leaders must have prior experience of being in a Balint Group for a sufficient* length of time.
LIST.3: Leaders should have co-led with an accredited leader as part of their training who is invited to provide a report/reference to the accrediting society.
LIST.4: Leaders should have a supervisor who has sufficient** knowledge of their work to be able to provide a report/reference to the accrediting society.
LIST.5: Leaders should be evaluated prior to accreditation according to the following criteria:
LIST.6: Leaders should receive adequate and continuing supervision.

SUBLIST.1: that they encourage the development of a safe and free environment within the group and are aware of the importance of protecting the boundaries of the group
SUBLIST.2: that they focus the work on an exploration of the doctor-patient relationship rather than seeking solutions or teaching
SUBLIST.3: that they are open to learning about their personal style in leading a group and aware that their attitudes and responses will influence the dynamics of the group
SUBLIST.4: that they have an awareness of group processes and unconscious processes that are likely to affect the primary task of the group
SUBLIST.5: that they recognize that becoming an accredited Balint leader is a not an end but a beginning

CERTIFICATES.*: * to be determined by accrediting societies
CERTIFICATES.**: ** may not be possible at present in some societies

GALLERY_TITLES.26: 2019 May 24-27, The annual conference on Balint work took place in Aachen, Germany. The conference was attended by delegations from Russia, Great Britain, Holland, France and others. The conference was attended by Chairman of the Armenian Balint Union I. Khanamiryan, Vice President I. Ghazaryan, Board Member, Chairman of the Moscow Balint Union A.K. Avagimyan, as well as members of the Association H. Hakobyan and Y.Hakobyan. This year's conference was dedicated to Armenia. The members of the Armenian delegation presented the peculiarities of the Balint movement in Armenia. The representatives of different countries also had the opportunity to get acquainted with the Armenian culture,  art and  number of dishes.

OUR_HISTORY.TITLE: About Us

TEXT.1: The Balint movement has long been an integral part of professional culture among specialists in helping professions in developed countries, and their openness to Balint work has become an indicator of their level of professionalism. The positive impact of Balint work on the quality of professional relations in the field of helping professions is unquestionable in the scientific community.
TEXT.2: The Balint movement is currently gaining popularity in Russia. Aware of their social and professional responsibility, members of Moscow Balint Society consider it important to base their work on the principles of scientificity, openness and legitimacy.
TEXT.3: The Moscow Balint Society was founded on August 3, 2017 (the record of a non-profit organization was included in Russia’s Unified State Register of Legal Entities on August 3, 2017; state registration number: 117770012379) as a public non-profit organization for assistance to doctors, psychologists, medical and social workers, acting in accordance with the organization Statute under the authority of the organization Board.
TEXT.4: The Moscow Balint Society is guided by the high professional and ethical standards of the Balint work, described in the Statute and Regulations on Balint Group leadership of the International Balint Federation (IBF).
TEXT.5: The Moscow Balint Society goals are: professional training of BG leaders, dissemination of the Balint ideas and knowledge among the professional community at large, promotion of Balint work in accordance with the requirement of the International Balint Federation (IBF).
TEXT.6: Russian translation of Dr. Heide Otten’s The Theory and Practice of Balint Group Work: Analyzing Professional Relationships

BA.TITLE: Armenian Balint Society
BA.PARAGRAPH_1: Although Armenian Balint Society was established in 2017, the Balint movement in Armenia began in 2014, when a group of psychologists from Yerevan State University Center of Applied Psychology began training for the Balint Group Leader Certification. The training consisted of four modules developed and implemented by the senior lecturer of M. Sechenov First Moscow State Medical University, certified counsellor, certified Balint Group leader, Member of the British Balint Society, President of the Balint Society of Moscow Angela Avagimyan, who later became one of the founders and president of Armenian Balint Society. The training was held for two years after which 8 participants were certified as the All-Russian Professional Psychotherapeutic League Balint Group Leaders.
BA.PARAGRAPH_2: Three international conferences on Balint Movement, two in Yerevan (in 2015 and 2016), one in Moscow (in 2017), were organized by Angela Avagimyan and YSU Center of Applied Psychology, during which the leading specialists from German and British Balint Societys performed master-classes and shared their experiences. Thus, the two-year trainings as well as the three international conferences stimulated the development of the Balint Movement in Armenia. In parallel with this the active agitation was held within helping professionals who finally formed the first Armenian Balint Groups.
BA.PARAGRAPH_3: So, starting from 2016, the groups have been managed by Armenian specialists (D. Gevorgyan, I.Khanamiryan, I. Ghazaryan, E. Asribabayan, A.Sargsyan, M. Sargsyan), and gradually more and more people started to involve in the work of those groups -  psychologists, medical doctors, nurses, social workers, teachers. The Balint Groups were spreading in professional circles and finally in 2017 a decision was made to establish the Armenian Balint Society, presiding over Angela Avagimyan, who played an indispensable role in the Balint movement in Armenia.
BA.PARAGRAPH_4: The Society is still making its first steps to psychologically support the helping professionals and is actively engaged in the involvement of new members, structural development, establishment of international relations and dissemination of  Balint culture in Armenia.
